meta.author: Sam Cogan
meta.disclaimer: Mappings are indicative only. Assessment suitability depends on task design, criteria, and context. Use academic judgement.

changes: Added verbs: describe, apply, perform, analyse, investigate, evaluate, produce, create (multi-level guidance, stems, mappings).
Expanded verb library across Bloom levels with synonyms, stems, task ideas, and mapping notes.
Expanded assessment format catalogue with stable IDs and richer metadata/tags.
Added optional tags for workload/scalability/authenticity/AI-risk and delivery modes.
Added lightweight compatibility notes and tighter validation rules.
Introduced multi-level verb support via stemsByLevel and levelGuidance (verbs may legitimately fit multiple Bloom levels depending on object and constraints).
Added diagnosticStrength to help users distinguish verbs that are strongly level-diagnostic vs context-dependent.
Expanded validationRules to include optional multi-level fields while retaining backwards compatibility.

migrationNotes: Existing keys are retained. New fields are optional: meta.changelog, meta.compatibility, assessmentFormats[].tags, verbs[].tags.workloadHint/aiRiskHint/dependsOn.
allowedSuitabilityValues adds 'context-dependent' (apps that validate strictly should accept this new enum or treat it as 'medium').

New optional fields on verbs: stemsByLevel (object of levelId -> stems array), levelGuidance (object of levelId -> guidance string), diagnosticStrength ('high'|'medium'|'low'). Existing fields remain unchanged.

levels.label: Remember
levels.shortDefinition: Recall facts, terms, and basic concepts.

commonPitfalls: Over-claiming cognitive demand in the LO while assessing only recall.

levels.label: Understand
levels.shortDefinition: Explain ideas or concepts; show comprehension.

commonPitfalls: Confusing 'explain' with critique; no criteria or justification required.

levels.label: Apply
levels.shortDefinition: Use information in new situations; perform procedures.

commonPitfalls: Calling something 'apply' when it requires judgement and criteria (evaluate).

levels.label: Analyse
levels.shortDefinition: Break material into parts; examine relationships and patterns.

commonPitfalls: Listing differences without explaining significance or relationships.

levels.label: Evaluate
levels.shortDefinition: Make judgements using criteria and evidence.

commonPitfalls: Judgement without explicit criteria; opinion-only responses.

levels.label: Create
levels.shortDefinition: Produce new or original work by integrating elements.

meaning.short: Identify similarities and differences and explain their significance.
meaning.expanded: Requires examining elements and relationships, not just listing features. Stronger responses explain why similarities/differences matter in context.

taskIdeas.title: Criteria-based comparison matrix

formatMappings.rationale: Cases naturally provide context and competing options; comparison can be anchored to explicit criteria.
designNotes: Provide a comparison framework (e.g., criteria table).
Require significance/implications to avoid descriptive listing.

formatMappings.rationale: Reports can support structured comparative evaluation if criteria are specified.
designNotes: Include a section heading that explicitly requires comparison against criteria.

formatMappings.rationale: Possible with scenario-based items but often collapses into recall unless carefully designed.
designNotes: Use vignettes + 'best answer' with rationale prompts if supported.

meaning.short: State the meaning of a term or concept accurately.
meaning.expanded: Requires accurate recall and clear boundaries (what it is / is not). In many disciplines, a strong definition also includes essential features and a brief example.

learningOutcomeStems: Define X using appropriate disciplinary terminology.
Define X and give one example and one non-example to show boundaries.
Define the key terms used in Y and use them consistently in subsequent work.

formatMappings.rationale: Well-designed items can check precise recall of terminology quickly at scale.
designNotes: Prefer application-flavoured items (short scenarios) to reduce pure memorisation.
Use item analysis to remove ambiguous distractors.

formatMappings.rationale: Short responses allow checking accuracy while requiring learners to generate (not recognise) definitions.
designNotes: Require an example/non-example to reduce rote copying.
Use tight word limits and marking keys.

formatMappings.rationale: Portfolios can include definitions but are rarely the most efficient main evidence for recall.
designNotes: If used, embed definitions inside artefact annotations rather than standalone lists.

remember: Define X using appropriate disciplinary terminology.
Define X and give one example and one non-example to show boundaries.
Define the key terms used in Y and use them consistently in subsequent work.

levelGuidance.remember: Focus on accurate recall/recognition with minimal interpretation.
levelGuidance.understand: Ask for meaning, explanation, or faithful summary; avoid judgement unless criteria are given.

learningOutcomeStems: Identify X in Y (e.g., features, components, issues) from the provided material.

formatMappings.rationale: Short answers can require learners to point to and name elements, with minimal justification.

formatMappings.rationale: In skills contexts, identification can be observed during performance (e.g., selecting correct tool/setting).
designNotes: Use checklist + brief probing questions.

meaning.short: Make an idea clear by describing how or why it works.
meaning.expanded: Strong explanations connect concepts, include causal language, and use appropriate examples. The cognitive demand rises if explanation is anchored to evidence, mechanisms, or a specific context.

learningOutcomeStems: Explain how X works and illustrate your explanation with an example.
Explain why X leads to Y in the given context, using evidence from Z.
Explain the trade-offs between X and Y for audience Z.

taskIdeas.title: Teach-back video (micro)
taskIdeas.description: Record a 3–5 minute teach-back explaining a concept to a novice audience, using one worked example.

formatMappings.rationale: Prompts can demand causal/relational explanation in a constrained space, reducing waffle.
designNotes: Use 'because' prompts and require an example.
Mark for accuracy + coherence + example relevance.

formatMappings.rationale: Oral explanation can reveal understanding through questioning and clarification.
designNotes: Include live questions that test transfer to a new example.

formatMappings.rationale: Possible via extended response items but typical MCQ designs assess recognition rather than explanation.
designNotes: If used, include short-answer explanation items rather than pure MCQ.

understand: Explain how X works and illustrate your explanation with an example.
Explain why X leads to Y in the given context, using evidence from Z.
Explain the trade-offs between X and Y for audience Z.
analyse: Explain how X leads to Y by analysing the mechanism and linking each step to evidence from Z.
Explain differences in outcomes across cases by analysing underlying assumptions, variables, or conditions.

levelGuidance.understand: Focus on explaining meaning/mechanisms or summarising with fidelity; avoid judgement unless criteria are provided.
levelGuidance.analyse: Require relationships, patterns, causes, or implications; not just listing.

meaning.short: Condense material to its essential points without distorting meaning.
meaning.expanded: A good summary prioritises key ideas, maintains logical order, and uses the learner’s own structuring. Cognitive demand increases when summarising for a purpose or audience.

learningOutcomeStems: Summarise X for audience Y in no more than Z words, retaining the key argument and evidence.
Summarise the main findings of X and state their implications for Y.
Summarise the steps of process X as a reusable checklist.

taskIdeas.title: Executive summary

formatMappings.rationale: Reports often require concise summaries and can be assessed for relevance, coherence, and fidelity.
designNotes: Specify audience and purpose.
Use word limits and a marking key for 'essential points'.

formatMappings.rationale: Posters demand concise selection and visual prioritisation of key ideas.

formatMappings.rationale: Quizzes can check recognition of main ideas but not the ability to summarise authentically.
designNotes: If used, include short constructed responses.

understand: Summarise X for audience Y in no more than Z words, retaining the key argument and evidence.
Summarise the main findings of X and state their implications for Y.
Summarise the steps of process X as a reusable checklist.
analyse: Summarise X and highlight the underlying structure (claims, evidence, assumptions) and what it implies for Y.

levelGuidance.understand: Focus on explaining meaning/mechanisms or summarising with fidelity; avoid judgement unless criteria are provided.
levelGuidance.analyse: Require relationships, patterns, causes, or implications; not just listing.

meaning.short: Show you can carry out a procedure or use a method correctly.
meaning.expanded: Requires observable performance or a worked example. Strong evidence includes correct sequencing, appropriate tool choice, and explanation of decisions where relevant.

learningOutcomeStems: Demonstrate how to use X to achieve Y, following appropriate safety/quality requirements.
Demonstrate the method for solving X, showing your workings at each step.
Demonstrate correct use of X in scenario Y and explain key choices.

taskIdeas.title: Guided practical + short probe

Include brief probing questions for decision points.

formatMappings.rationale: A walkthrough/demo captures both doing and explaining, supporting judgement of understanding and skill.

Ask for a short 'what would you do if…' variant question.

formatMappings.rationale: Reports can evidence method use, but may miss whether the learner can actually perform under constraints.

Demonstrate correct use of X in scenario Y and explain key choices.

meaning.expanded: Typically requires building, configuring, or executing something in a real or simulated environment. Evidence improves with tests, constraints, and traceability from requirements to outcomes.

learningOutcomeStems: Implement X to meet Y requirements, and verify it using Z tests/criteria.
Implement a solution to X and document the steps so another person could reproduce it.

Recommend improvements to X based on evidence from data/user feedback, and prioritise them.
Recommend whether X should be adopted, including risks, mitigations, and success metrics.

taskIdeas.title: Decision memo
taskIdeas.description: Write a decision memo to a stakeholder recommending an option, with a criteria table and risk/mitigation section.

formatMappings.rationale: Reports/memos naturally support recommendation structures and traceability to evidence.
designNotes: Require explicit criteria and constraints.
Include 'what would change your mind' prompt.

formatMappings.rationale: Presentations allow persuasion and can be stress-tested via questioning.
designNotes: Include live Q&A and require a slide on trade-offs/risks.

formatMappings.rationale: A viva can test whether recommendations are owned and defensible, not generated.
designNotes: Ask learners to re-recommend under a changed constraint.

evaluate: Recommend an approach to X for context Y, justifying your choice using criteria Z.
Recommend improvements to X based on evidence from data/user feedback, and prioritise them.
Recommend whether X should be adopted, including risks, mitigations, and success metrics.
create: Recommend a change plan for X and produce an implementation roadmap with milestones and success metrics.
Recommend improvements to X and create a prioritised backlog with justification and evaluation measures.

levelGuidance.evaluate: Focus on judgement using explicit criteria and evidence; include trade-offs, limitations, or counterarguments.
levelGuidance.create: Require an artefact under constraints with rationale/iteration.

meaning.short: Create an original piece by assembling elements into a coherent product.
meaning.expanded: Composition can be creative or technical (e.g., writing, media, code, music). Evidence improves with constraints, audience specification, and a rationale that explains choices.

learningOutcomeStems: Compose X for audience Y that achieves purpose Z, explaining key choices.
Compose a short piece that demonstrates X technique and meets the given constraints.
Compose documentation/instructions that enable a novice to complete task X.

taskIdeas.title: Constrained composition
taskIdeas.description: Create a piece under explicit constraints (length, audience, required elements) and include a brief rationale for choices.

formatMappings.rationale: Portfolios can capture composed artefacts plus reflective rationale and iteration.
designNotes: Require annotations explaining choices and revisions.

formatMappings.rationale: Projects can support composition as part of a larger deliverable with constraints and feedback.
designNotes: Include stakeholder/audience constraints and review cycles.

formatMappings.rationale: Presentations can showcase composed work but may not fully evidence the composition process.
designNotes: If used, pair with submission of the artefact and a rationale.

create: Compose X for audience Y that achieves purpose Z, explaining key choices.
Compose a short piece that demonstrates X technique and meets the given constraints.
Compose documentation/instructions that enable a novice to complete task X.
understand: Compose X for audience Y that achieves purpose Z, explaining key choices.
Compose a short piece that demonstrates X technique and meets the given constraints.

levelGuidance.create: Focus on producing an artefact under constraints; include rationale, iteration, and success criteria.
levelGuidance.understand: Ask for meaning, explanation, or faithful summary; avoid judgement unless criteria are given.

verbs.meaning: Give an account of key features, characteristics, or processes in a way that shows comprehension (may include context and examples).
learningOutcomeStems: Describe the key features of {concept/process} using appropriate terminology.
Describe how {process/system} works, including its main stages/components.
Describe the differences between {A} and {B} in terms of {dimension}.
taskIdeas: Write a short structured description of {concept} for a novice audience, using an example.
Create an annotated diagram that describes the parts of {system} and what each part does.
Record a 2–3 minute explanation that describes the steps of {procedure} and common errors.

formatMappings.notes: Works well when prompts require accurate, relevant features; can include context to demonstrate understanding.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Answer 3 prompts describing {concept}, {example}, and {implication}.

formatMappings.notes: Can check recall/understanding if questions are well-written; risk of drifting to recall-only without context.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Short-answer quiz items: 'Describe X and give one example'.

formatMappings.notes: Suitable when description is supported by visuals/structure; depends on marking criteria.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Poster describing a system with labelled parts and brief functional descriptions.

formatMappings.notes: Oral description can show understanding; depends on prompts and time limits.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Mini-presentation describing a process and its purpose for a given audience.

remember: Describe (recall) the main parts/steps of {topic} from memory.
Describe key terms related to {topic} (definitions and labels).
understand: Describe {topic} and explain the role/significance of each key element.
Describe {topic} using an example that illustrates the concept in context.

levelGuidance.remember: Description is primarily listing features/steps without explanation of significance.
levelGuidance.understand: Description includes organisation, correct terminology, and context/examples showing comprehension.

verbs.meaning: Use knowledge, methods, or rules in a concrete situation to achieve a goal or solve a problem.
learningOutcomeStems: Apply {method/framework} to {case/problem} to produce {output}.
Apply {rule/procedure} correctly to complete {task}.
Apply {concept} to interpret/solve {scenario}.
taskIdeas: Apply a taught method to a new dataset and submit the resulting analysis with brief commentary.
Apply a policy/framework to a case study and produce a justified action plan.
Apply a procedure in a practical setting and document steps and outcomes.

formatMappings.notes: Directly captures procedural performance; depends on clarity of criteria and conditions.
formatMappings.taskExamples: In-lab task: apply {procedure} to achieve {specified result}.

formatMappings.notes: Applying algorithms/techniques is observable via artefacts and tests; depends on task authenticity.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Implement {algorithm} and apply it to given inputs; pass unit tests.

formatMappings.notes: Good when 'apply' is to a realistic scenario; depends on case complexity and marking criteria.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Apply {framework} to a case and produce recommendations and rationale.

formatMappings.notes: Can show application in dynamic environments; depends on debrief/trace evidence.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Run a simulation applying {rules} and explain decisions made at key points.

understand: Apply {concept} to a simple, guided example and explain each step.
apply: Apply {method} independently to a new problem to produce a correct solution/output.
analyse: Apply {method} and then analyse the results to identify patterns, assumptions, or limitations.

levelGuidance.understand: Application is guided/scaffolded and focuses on explaining steps rather than independent transfer.
levelGuidance.apply: Independent use in a new situation; correctness and appropriateness of method are central.
levelGuidance.analyse: Application is followed by analytic interpretation (patterns/assumptions/relationships).

verbs.meaning: Carry out a procedure or skill to an expected standard under defined conditions.
learningOutcomeStems: Perform {procedure/skill} safely and accurately in {context}.
Perform {task} to meet {standard/criteria}.
Perform {role/process} in a simulated or authentic setting.
taskIdeas: Observed skill check: perform {skill} with a checklist and brief reflection on errors.
OSCE-style station: perform {task} within time limit and explain decision points.
Live demo: perform a workflow and troubleshoot when given a constraint.

formatMappings.notes: Direct observation supports validity for performance; depends on rubric/checklist quality.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Demo performing {workflow} while narrating key choices.

formatMappings.notes: Best match for hands-on skills and procedures; depends on conditions and resources.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Perform {lab technique} and record outputs in a log.

formatMappings.notes: Can probe reasoning behind performance; depends on pairing with artefact/observation.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Viva after performance: explain why you did X at step Y.

formatMappings.notes: Portfolio can evidence repeated performance over time; depends on verification/authenticity.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Portfolio of performance logs + supervisor sign-off.

remember: Perform a rehearsed procedure exactly as taught (routine conditions).
apply: Perform {skill} in a new or variable context, adapting within constraints.
evaluate: Perform {skill} and evaluate your performance against criteria, proposing improvements.

levelGuidance.remember: Reproduction of a routine with minimal adaptation.
levelGuidance.apply: Competent execution in context, including appropriate adjustments.
levelGuidance.evaluate: Includes judgement about quality (self/peer) using explicit criteria.

verbs.meaning: Break information into parts to examine relationships, patterns, assumptions, or causes and effects.
learningOutcomeStems: Analyse {data/text/case} to identify {patterns/relationships} and explain their significance.
Analyse {problem} by separating it into components and evaluating how they interact.
Analyse {argument} to identify assumptions, evidence, and reasoning.
taskIdeas: Analyse a dataset and produce a short insights memo explaining key patterns and implications.
Analyse a case study and map causes, stakeholders, and constraints before proposing options.
Analyse an argument by annotating claims/evidence and identifying missing evidence.

formatMappings.notes: Reports support structured analysis with evidence; depends on criteria (relationships/implications).
formatMappings.taskExamples: Analysis report: identify patterns in data and justify interpretations.

formatMappings.notes: Often includes analysis of results; depends on requiring interpretation not just computation.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Lab report section: analyse results and discuss sources of error/meaning.

formatMappings.notes: Cases can elicit analysis of relationships/causes; depends on complexity and prompts.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Analyse case using framework; identify drivers and trade-offs.

formatMappings.notes: Good for probing analytic reasoning; depends on having an artefact to discuss.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Viva: walk through your analysis choices and what they imply.

understand: Analyse (guided) a simple example to show how parts relate (with prompts/scaffolds).
analyse: Analyse {material} independently to identify relationships/patterns and explain significance.
evaluate: Analyse {options/evidence} and evaluate which interpretation/option is best using criteria.

levelGuidance.understand: Heavily scaffolded analysis focused on explaining relationships in a simple example.
levelGuidance.evaluate: Analysis is used to support a judgement with explicit criteria.

verbs.meaning: Systematically inquire into a question/problem by gathering evidence, analysing it, and drawing defensible conclusions.
learningOutcomeStems: Investigate {question/problem} using {method} and present evidence-based findings.
Investigate the causes/factors influencing {phenomenon} and explain your conclusions.
Investigate {system/process} to identify issues and propose evidence-based improvements.
taskIdeas: Mini research task: investigate a question, justify method, analyse evidence, and report findings.
Diagnostic investigation: investigate a failure, collect logs/evidence, identify root causes.
Workplace-style investigation: investigate stakeholder needs and produce a brief with findings.

formatMappings.notes: Projects accommodate inquiry cycles (question→method→evidence→findings); depends on scope control.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Project: investigate X, collect data, analyse, present findings and limitations.

formatMappings.notes: Reports suit method + evidence + conclusions; depends on requiring traceability.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Investigation report with method, evidence table, and justified conclusions.

formatMappings.notes: Supports iterative investigation artefacts over time; depends on verification and curation criteria.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Portfolio: research log, evidence summaries, reflections, final conclusions.

formatMappings.notes: Can communicate findings; depends on requiring evidence and Q&A.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Present investigation findings and defend choices in Q&A.

apply: Investigate using a prescribed method/tool to gather evidence and report results.
analyse: Investigate by selecting appropriate evidence sources and analysing relationships/causes.
evaluate: Investigate and evaluate the strength/limitations of evidence and methods used.
create: Investigate and produce a novel artefact/solution informed by findings and constraints.

levelGuidance.apply: Uses a given method; focus is correct execution of investigative steps.
levelGuidance.analyse: Emphasis on interpreting evidence and explaining relationships/causes.
levelGuidance.evaluate: Emphasis on judging evidence quality, method fit, and uncertainty/limits.
levelGuidance.create: Findings inform the design/production of an original output.

verbs.meaning: Make a judgement about quality, value, or effectiveness using explicit criteria and evidence.
learningOutcomeStems: Evaluate {option/solution} against {criteria} and justify your judgement using evidence.
Evaluate the effectiveness of {approach/intervention} using {data/standards}.
Evaluate {work/product} and propose improvements based on criteria.
taskIdeas: Evaluate two approaches using a weighted criteria matrix and justify the recommendation.
Evaluate an artefact against a rubric and produce a feedback report with priorities.
Evaluate an intervention using evidence and discuss limitations/uncertainty.

formatMappings.notes: Peer review naturally aligns with criteria-based judgement; depends on rubric quality and training.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Peer-review using rubric + justification + improvement suggestions.

formatMappings.notes: Works when criteria and evidence are explicit; risk of opinion-only without structure.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Essay: evaluate theory X using criteria Y and evidence Z.

formatMappings.notes: Allows probing criteria and evidence; depends on artefacts and questioning.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Viva: defend your evaluation and respond to counter-arguments.

formatMappings.notes: Reports suit structured evaluation (criteria, evidence, judgement); depends on requiring traceability.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Evaluation report including criteria, evidence, judgement, and recommendations.

analyse: Evaluate (preparatory) by analysing evidence and identifying relevant criteria (no final judgement required yet).
evaluate: Evaluate {thing} by applying explicit criteria and evidence to reach a justified judgement.
create: Evaluate and refine {artefact} iteratively, documenting decisions and improvements.

levelGuidance.analyse: Focus on setting up criteria/evidence and understanding trade-offs; judgement may be tentative.
levelGuidance.create: Evaluation is used to iterate and improve an original artefact.

verbs.meaning: Generate an artefact/output that meets stated requirements; may range from templated outputs to original work depending on constraints.
learningOutcomeStems: Produce {artefact} that meets {requirements/constraints} for {audience/purpose}.
Produce a {deliverable} integrating {elements} and justifying key design choices.
Produce {output} and document the process and decisions used.
taskIdeas: Produce a short policy brief for a defined audience with constraints on length and evidence.
Produce a working prototype (code/design) that meets acceptance criteria.
Produce a portfolio artefact and a short rationale explaining choices made.

formatMappings.notes: Projects support creation of substantive outputs; depends on originality and constraints.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Produce a prototype meeting acceptance criteria + short rationale.

formatMappings.notes: Portfolios evidence production over time; depends on curation and authenticity checks.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Produce multiple artefacts across weeks with reflection and evidence of process.

formatMappings.notes: Briefs can structure production with constraints; depends on evaluating against requirements.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Produce a brief + artefact responding to client constraints.

formatMappings.notes: Suitable where artefact is produced hands-on; depends on resources and criteria.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Produce {artefact} in a studio/lab session with rubric.

understand: Produce a simple representation of {concept} (e.g., diagram/summary) to demonstrate understanding.
apply: Produce {standard output} by correctly applying a prescribed method/template.
create: Produce an original artefact that integrates elements and meets constraints for a purpose/audience.

levelGuidance.apply: Output follows a prescribed method/template; success is correctness/completeness.
levelGuidance.create: Output requires design decisions, integration, and originality within constraints.

verbs.meaning: Bring elements together to form a new whole; generate an original product/plan/solution under constraints.
learningOutcomeStems: Create {artefact/solution} that addresses {need/problem} within {constraints}.
Create and justify a plan/strategy for {goal} based on {evidence/requirements}.
Create a novel approach to {problem} and evaluate its effectiveness against criteria.
taskIdeas: Create a design proposal for a client with constraints, including rationale and trade-offs.
Create a working solution and iterate based on testing/feedback.
Create an intervention plan, justify decisions, and outline evaluation measures.

formatMappings.notes: Projects allow original creation with constraints and iteration; depends on rubric emphasising decisions and evidence.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Create a solution/prototype; document iterations and decisions.

formatMappings.notes: Briefs capture constraints, audience, and rationale; depends on assessment criteria.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Create a brief + artefact; justify design choices.

formatMappings.notes: Portfolios support iterative creation evidence; depends on authentic process evidence.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Portfolio of drafts, feedback, and final artefact.

formatMappings.notes: Presenting a created solution can evidence reasoning; depends on Q&A and artefact quality.
formatMappings.taskExamples: Pitch your created solution and defend trade-offs in Q&A.

apply: Create (guided) a product using a provided template/process, adapting to minor constraints.
evaluate: Create and then evaluate/refine the artefact against explicit criteria, documenting improvements.
create: Create an original artefact/solution integrating elements and meeting constraints for a defined purpose.

levelGuidance.apply: Creation is largely templated; main demand is correct application and minor adaptation.
levelGuidance.evaluate: Creation includes explicit judgement/refinement cycles based on criteria and evidence.
levelGuidance.create: Emphasis on originality, integration, constraints, and defensible design decisions.

recommendations.avoidVerbDuplication: If you add a near-synonym verb, link via synonyms/relatedVerbs instead of copying full entries.
recommendations.keepMappingsIndicative: Always include a rationale + at least one design note; avoid absolute language.
recommendations.multiLevelVerbs: A verb may fit multiple Bloom levels depending on the object and constraints. Use stemsByLevel to disambiguate the intended cognitive demand.
